description: Mid 17th century French tabis, from Arabic عَتَّابِيّ‎ (ʕattābiyy), ultimately from Arabic الْعَتَّابِيَّة‎ (al-ʕattābiyya), a quarter of Baghdad (named for a Prince عَتَّاب‎ (ʕattāb)) which is associated with the manufacture of a certain type of waved silk. See also taffeta, another type of silk whose name derives from the Persian تافته‎ (tâfta, “woven cloth”) and shares a similar etymological origin.

entries.meaning: Having a wavy or watered appearance.
(countable, uncountable) A kind of waved silk, usually called watered silk, manufactured like taffeta, but thicker and stronger. The watering is given to it by calendering.
(uncountable) A mixture of lime with shells, gravel, or stones, in equal proportions, with an equal proportion of water. When dry, this becomes as hard as rock.
(countable, archaic) An old maid or gossip.

verbs.description: tabby (third-person singular simple present tabbies, present participle tabbying, simple past and past participle tabbied)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give a wavy or watered appearance to (a textile).
